head.title: Learning to Live With Background Radiation

hedline.hl1: Learning to Live With Background Radiation

abstract.p: Lewis Friedman letter responds to Miriam Goodman's June 25 letter on his alleged lack of knowledge about health hazards of low-level radiation (S)

block.p: In her letter published June 25 [''Even Background Levels of Radiation Are Harmful''], Miriam Goodman assumes, incorrectly, that I am uninformed about potential health hazards of low-level radiation.
She missed the point of my earlier letter. I know about these hazards, but I still have dental X-rays when needed. Life includes many unavoidable risks.
In her letter published June 25 [''Even Background Levels of Radiation Are Harmful''], Miriam Goodman assumes, incorrectly, that I am uninformed about potential health hazards of low-level radiation.
She missed the point of my earlier letter. I know about these hazards, but I still have dental X-rays when needed. Life includes many unavoidable risks.

A real reduction of the level of ''natural'' ionizing radiation would bankrupt the country. I did not argue against a cleanup of nuclear waste, but there comes a point of diminishing returns. The nuclear waste at Brookhaven National Laboratory approaches this point: It is worth noting that some of the lowest levels of natural radiation background have been achieved at Brookhaven Lab.

My suggestion to anyone concerned about natural radiation is that they are free to spend their own money to try to clean up the radiation in their own backyards. I do not like to see tax money wasted. If they cannot find any radioactivity in their soil, they can work on a cosmic radiation shield for their homes.
